what is the Pakistan Bureau of Statistic: The Pakistan Bureau of Statistics (PBS) is the central body responsible for collecting, compiling, and disseminating statistical information in Pakistan.
PBS provides data related to population, agriculture, industry, trade, and other sectors to help in policy-making and economic planning.
It conducts important surveys, such as the population census, economic surveys, and agricultural statistics.
what is the Ministry of Foreign Affairs: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs is responsible for managing Pakistan's diplomatic relations with other countries and representing the country in international organizations.
It plays a key role in formulating foreign policy, negotiating treaties, and managing Pakistan's embassies abroad.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs is located in Islamabad and is headed by the Foreign Minister.
what is the Pakistan International Airli: Pakistan International Airlines (PIA) is the national flag carrier airline of Pakistan, providing domestic and international air services.
Founded in 1955, PIA is a key player in Pakistan's transportation sector, connecting the country with major global cities.
PIA is owned by the government of Pakistan and has faced various challenges but remains an integral part of Pakistan's aviation history.
what is the National Disaster Management: The National Disaster Management Authority (NDMA) is the government agency responsible for coordinating disaster response and management in Pakistan.
It works to reduce the risks of natural disasters such as earthquakes, floods, and droughts, and helps in providing relief during emergencies.
NDMA collaborates with provincial disaster management authorities to ensure efficient disaster relief efforts.
what is Islam: Islam is a monotheistic religion that believes in one God, Allah, and follows the teachings of the Prophet Muhammad (PBUH).
The followers of Islam are known as Muslims, and they believe that Muhammad is the last prophet of God.
Islam teaches that the purpose of life is to worship Allah and live according to His guidance as revealed in the Quran and Hadith.
who is Prophet Muhammad (PBUH): Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) is the final messenger of Allah, born in Mecca in 570 CE.
He is considered the Seal of the Prophets in Islam, meaning no prophets will come after him.
His life and teachings are recorded in the Hadith, and his revelations were compiled into the Quran.
what is the Quran: The Quran is the holy book of Islam, believed to be the direct word of Allah as revealed to Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) over 23 years.
The Quran contains 114 chapters, known as Surahs, and addresses all aspects of life, including morality, law, and guidance on worship.
Muslims believe that the Quran is the final, unaltered word of God and it serves as a manual for living a righteous life.
what is the meaning of Islam: Islam comes from the Arabic word 'Salaam', which means peace, and is derived from the root word 'Aslama', meaning to submit or surrender.
In Islam, peace is achieved by submitting to the will of Allah and following His teachings.
The word Islam can be translated as 'the path to peace' or 'surrender to God'.
what are the five pillars of Islam: The Five Pillars of Islam are the core principles that guide the life of every Muslim. They are:
1. Shahada (Faith): The declaration that there is no god but Allah, and Muhammad is His messenger.
2. Salat (Prayer): Performing five daily prayers facing Mecca, including Fajr, Dhuhr, Asr, Maghrib, and Isha.
3. Zakat (Almsgiving): Giving a portion of oneâ€™s wealth to the poor and needy, usually 2.5% annually.
4. Sawm (Fasting): Fasting during the month of Ramadan from dawn till sunset, refraining from food, drink, and other physical needs.
5. Hajj (Pilgrimage): The pilgrimage to Mecca, which Muslims must undertake at least once in their lifetime, provided they are able.
what is the importance of the Kaaba: The Kaaba is a cube-shaped building in the center of the Masjid al-Haram in Mecca, Saudi Arabia.
It is considered the holiest site in Islam, and Muslims around the world face the Kaaba during their prayers (Salat).
The Kaaba is the focal point for the Hajj pilgrimage, where millions of Muslims gather every year to perform sacred rituals.
what is Ramadan: Ramadan is the ninth month of the Islamic calendar, and it is considered the holiest month for Muslims.
During Ramadan, Muslims fast from dawn until sunset, refraining from food, drink, and other physical needs.
It is a time of spiritual reflection, increased devotion, charity, and community, culminating in the celebration of Eid al-Fitr at the end of the month.
what is Eid al-Fitr: Eid al-Fitr, known as the Festival of Breaking the Fast, marks the end of Ramadan.
It is a celebratory occasion, where Muslims gather for prayers, feasts, and give zakat (charity) to the poor.
Eid al-Fitr is one of the two major Islamic festivals, the other being Eid al-Adha.
what is the significance of Hajj: Hajj is the annual pilgrimage to Mecca, required of every Muslim who is physically and financially able to undertake it.
It is one of the Five Pillars of Islam and represents a Muslimâ€™s submission to Allah, as well as the unity of Muslims worldwide.
Hajj takes place in the 12th month of the Islamic calendar and involves performing a series of rituals, such as walking around the Kaaba and praying at important sites in Mecca.
what is Zakat: Zakat is an obligatory form of almsgiving or charity, one of the Five Pillars of Islam.
Muslims are required to give a percentage (usually 2.5%) of their savings to those in need, helping to purify their wealth and assist the poor.
Zakat is considered a means of promoting social justice and helping those less fortunate.
who are the companions of Prophet Muhamm: The companions of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) are known as the Sahabah, and they were his closest followers and supporters.
Some of the most prominent companions include Abu Bakr, Umar ibn al-Khattab, Uthman ibn Affan, Ali ibn Abi Talib, and Aisha bint Abi Bakr.
The Sahabah played a significant role in spreading Islam and supporting the Prophet throughout his life.
what is Sharia law: Sharia is the Islamic legal system, derived from the Quran and Hadith, and it guides the personal, moral, and social conduct of Muslims.
Sharia law covers a wide range of topics, including criminal law, family law, finance, and worship practices.
Sharia aims to provide a just and ethical framework for living, promoting justice, equality, and morality.
what is Jihad: Jihad, in its original sense, means 'struggle' or 'striving' in the way of Allah.
It can refer to both personal struggles, such as striving to live a good life and follow Islamic teachings, as well as defensive warfare to protect Islam from oppression.
Jihad is often misunderstood and misused, but it fundamentally refers to striving for self-improvement and righteousness.
what is the Hadith: Hadith refers to the sayings, actions, and approvals of the Prophet Muhammad (PBUH).
The Hadith provides further clarification and elaboration on the Quran, helping Muslims understand and practice their faith.
Hadiths are collected in various books, such as Sahih Bukhari, Sahih Muslim, and others, and they are categorized into authentic (Sahih), weak (Da'if), and fabricated (Mawdu').
what is the difference between Sunni and: The primary difference between Sunni and Shia Islam lies in the succession of leadership after the death of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH).

Sunnis believe that the community should select the leader (caliph), which led to Abu Bakr being the first caliph. Shias believe that the leadership should remain within the Prophetâ€™s family, specifically Ali, the cousin, and son-in-law of Muhammad.

This difference has led to varying practices, rituals, and interpretations within the two branches, though both Sunni and Shia Muslims share core beliefs and practices, including the Quran and the Five Pillars.
what is the significance of Mecca: Mecca, located in Saudi Arabia, is the birthplace of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and the site of the Kaaba, the holiest structure in Islam.
Every year, millions of Muslims travel to Mecca to perform Hajj, and Muslims around the world pray facing Mecca five times a day.
Mecca is considered the spiritual heart of Islam, and it is revered by Muslims as the center of their faith.
what is the concept of angels in Islam: In Islam, angels are considered to be created by Allah from light, and they do not have free will like humans.
Angels perform various tasks, including delivering Allah's messages, recording deeds, and protecting and assisting believers.
Some of the most famous angels include Jibreel (Gabriel), who brought revelations to the prophets, and Israfil, who will blow the trumpet on the Day of Judgment.
what is the Day of Judgment: The Day of Judgment, or Yawm al-Qiyamah, is the day when all humans will be resurrected for accountability before Allah.
On this day, people will be judged based on their deeds, and their final destination will be either Paradise (Jannah) or Hell (Jahannam).
Muslims believe that this day is certain, and it will occur after the signs of the end of the world are fulfilled, as described in the Quran and Hadith.
what is the concept of Tawhid: Tawhid is the concept of the oneness of Allah in Islam. It asserts that Allah is the only God, without any partners or associates.
It is the most fundamental concept in Islam, emphasizing that Allah is unique in His essence, attributes, and actions.
Tawhid also means that everything in the universe is a sign of Allah's oneness and sovereignty.
what is the importance of Salah (prayer): Salah, the five daily prayers, is one of the most important pillars of Islam and a direct connection between Muslims and Allah.
Salah is a form of worship and a reminder of Allah's greatness. It helps Muslims to maintain mindfulness of Allah throughout the day.
The five prayers are Fajr (before dawn), Dhuhr (midday), Asr (afternoon), Maghrib (sunset), and Isha (night).
what is the role of the Mosque in Islam: The mosque is a place of worship and community gathering in Islam.
It serves as a center for prayers, religious education, and community events.
The mosque also plays an important role in providing space for social services and charitable activities.
what is the concept of Taqwa: Taqwa is the consciousness of Allah and being mindful of Him in all aspects of life.
It involves fear, love, and trust in Allah, and it guides a Muslim to live a righteous life by avoiding sins and doing good deeds.
Taqwa is often described as the quality of being pious and God-conscious, which leads to inner peace and protection from evil.
what is the concept of Barakah: Barakah refers to divine blessings or spiritual goodness that comes from Allah.
It can manifest in wealth, time, health, relationships, and other aspects of life.
Muslims believe that barakah comes from following Allahâ€™s commands and leading a righteous life.
what is the importance of Hajj: Hajj is a pilgrimage to Mecca, which every Muslim is required to undertake once in their lifetime if financially and physically able.
It is a powerful act of worship that symbolizes equality and unity among Muslims from all walks of life.
Hajj offers spiritual cleansing and the opportunity for forgiveness and renewal of faith.
what is the role of the Quran in Islam: The Quran is the final and unaltered word of Allah revealed to Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) over 23 years.
It serves as a complete guide for life, covering various aspects of faith, law, morality, and guidance.
The Quran is recited and memorized by millions of Muslims worldwide, and it is considered the foundation of Islamic beliefs and practices.
what is the significance of the Sunnah: Sunnah refers to the teachings, actions, and habits of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) that serve as a model for Muslims to follow.
The Sunnah complements the Quran, providing explanations and practical examples of how to live according to Islamic teachings.
The Hadith literature is a compilation of the sayings and actions of the Prophet Muhammad (PBUH), which forms the basis of the Sunnah.
what is Ihsan: Ihsan is the highest level of worship in Islam, meaning to worship Allah as if you can see Him, and if you cannot see Him, knowing that He sees you.
Ihsan is about performing deeds with excellence and sincerity, seeking Allahâ€™s pleasure in everything.
It involves kindness, compassion, and striving to improve oneâ€™s relationship with Allah.
what is Fiqh: Fiqh is the Islamic jurisprudence, the study and understanding of Islamic law and its practical application in daily life.
Fiqh covers a wide range of topics, from personal acts of worship to commercial transactions, marriage, and criminal justice.
Islamic scholars interpret the Quran and Sunnah to derive legal rulings, and these rulings are categorized into five main categories: obligatory, recommended, permissible, disliked, and forbidden.
what is the significance of the family i: In Islam, the family is considered the cornerstone of society, and it plays a key role in building a moral and harmonious community.
Islam teaches the importance of respecting parents, maintaining family ties, and being kind to one's spouse and children.
The rights and duties of family members are clearly outlined in the Quran and Hadith, emphasizing love, support, and cooperation.
what is the concept of Charity (Sadaqah): Sadaqah is voluntary charity that Muslims give to help those in need, and it can take various forms, including money, food, or time.
Sadaqah is not limited to material possessions, as helping others with a smile or offering support is also considered a form of charity.
Giving charity purifies wealth and promotes social justice, and it is highly encouraged in Islam.
what is the concept of Riba (interest): Riba, or interest, is prohibited in Islam as it is considered exploitative and unjust.
Islam encourages fair and ethical business transactions, and charging interest on loans is seen as a way of oppressing the borrower.
Muslims are encouraged to engage in trade and commerce that benefit both parties fairly.
what is the concept of Halal and Haram: Halal refers to actions or things that are permitted or lawful in Islam, while Haram refers to those that are forbidden.

Halal encompasses food, behavior, and business practices that conform to Islamic principles, while Haram includes actions like theft, dishonesty, and eating forbidden foods such as pork or consuming alcohol.
The concept of Halal and Haram helps Muslims to make ethical and responsible decisions in their daily lives.
what is the importance of the Day of Ara: The Day of Arafah occurs on the 9th day of Dhu al-Hijjah and is a significant day for Muslims, particularly those performing Hajj.
It is a day of supplication and forgiveness, as Muslims gather at the plain of Arafat to pray and seek Allah's mercy.
For those not performing Hajj, fasting on this day is recommended as it is a means of expiation for past sins.
what is the significance of Jannah (Para: Jannah is the eternal paradise promised by Allah to those who believe in Him and live righteous lives.
It is described as a place of unimaginable beauty and bliss, with rivers of milk, honey, and wine, gardens filled with fruits, and mansions made of gold and silver.
The ultimate reward in Jannah is the pleasure of Allah and eternal peace.
what is the concept of Tawbah (Repentanc: Tawbah is the act of repentance, where a person seeks forgiveness from Allah for their sins and returns to a path of righteousness.
It involves feeling regret for the wrongdoings, sincerely asking for Allah's forgiveness, and making a firm intention not to repeat the sin.
Tawbah is a means of purification and reconciliation with Allah.
what is the role of the Islamic calendar: The Islamic calendar, also known as the Hijri calendar, is based on the lunar cycle and is used to determine the dates of Islamic events and rituals.
The Islamic year starts with the migration of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) from Mecca to Medina, known as the Hijrah.
It is used to mark significant dates such as Ramadan, Hajj, Eid, and the Islamic New Year.
what is the concept of Zina (fornication: Zina refers to unlawful sexual relations outside of marriage, and it is strictly prohibited in Islam.
Islam encourages modesty and chastity, and upholds the sanctity of marriage as a sacred bond between husband and wife.
The punishment for zina is severe, but repentance and seeking forgiveness from Allah can lead to forgiveness.
what is the role of a Muslim in society: A Muslim's role in society is to act as a positive force by promoting justice, fairness, and compassion.
Muslims are encouraged to engage in acts of charity, uphold family values, work honestly, and be good neighbors.
A Muslim's conduct should reflect the principles of Islam, serving as an example for others.
what is the importance of fasting in Isl: Fasting during the month of Ramadan is an obligatory act of worship that allows Muslims to develop self-control, empathy for the less fortunate, and a closer connection to Allah.
It involves abstaining from food, drink, and other physical needs from dawn to sunset.
Fasting purifies the soul and encourages self-discipline and mindfulness.
what is the concept of Ghusl: Ghusl is a ritual purification required after certain acts, such as sexual activity, menstruation, or childbirth.
It is an important aspect of maintaining cleanliness and spiritual purity before performing acts of worship like prayer.
Ghusl involves washing the entire body with water.
what is the significance of the Battle o: The Battle of Badr was a pivotal battle in early Islamic history, fought between the Muslims of Medina and the Quraysh of Mecca.
Despite being outnumbered, the Muslims were victorious, and the battle is seen as a sign of Allah's support for the Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and his followers.
The Battle of Badr is celebrated for its lessons of faith, courage, and the power of relying on Allah.
what was the Battle of Uhud: The Battle of Uhud was fought in 625 CE between the early Muslims of Medina, led by Prophet Muhammad (PBUH), and the Quraysh of Mecca.

The battle took place near the mountain of Uhud, and although the Muslims initially had the upper hand, they suffered a setback when some archers left their posts, allowing the Quraysh to regroup and counterattack.
Although the Muslims did not win, the battle was a significant lesson in obedience and faith. It also demonstrated the perseverance and resilience of the Muslim community.
what was the Battle of Khandaq (Battle o: The Battle of Khandaq, also known as the Battle of the Trench, took place in 627 CE between the Muslims of Medina and a coalition of Quraysh and their allies.
The Muslims, under the leadership of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH), dug a trench around Medina to defend the city, preventing the enemy from entering.
The battle ended in a stalemate after a siege of several weeks, and it is often seen as a victory for the Muslims, as the enemy coalition eventually disbanded and returned home.
what was the significance of the Battle: The Battle of Badr, fought in 624 CE, is one of the most important battles in Islamic history.
It was the first major battle between the Muslims of Medina and the Quraysh of Mecca. Despite being outnumbered, the Muslims achieved a decisive victory.
The Battle of Badr is considered a turning point in the early history of Islam, as it boosted the morale of the Muslims and established them as a significant force.
what was the Battle of Hunayn: The Battle of Hunayn took place in 630 CE after the Muslims' conquest of Mecca, against a coalition of tribes from Hawazin and Thaqif.
Initially, the Muslims were overwhelmed due to the strength and surprise attack of the enemy, but after regrouping and with the support of Allah, the Muslims achieved victory.
The battle is significant because it demonstrated the importance of faith and reliance on Allah, even in difficult circumstances.
what was the Battle of Tabuk: The Battle of Tabuk occurred in 630 CE when Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) led an expedition to the northern borders of Arabia in response to rumors of an impending Byzantine invasion.

Although no actual battle took place, the Muslims' display of readiness and their journey to Tabuk is considered a victory in itself, as it showed the strength and determination of the Muslim community.
The Battle of Tabuk also marked the end of many potential threats to the Islamic state and solidified its position in the region.
what was the Battle of Yarmouk: The Battle of Yarmouk, fought in 636 CE, was a decisive battle between the forces of the Byzantine Empire and the Rashidun Caliphate.

Under the leadership of Khalid ibn al-Walid, the Muslim army achieved a decisive victory, which led to the fall of Byzantine control over Syria and paved the way for the spread of Islam throughout the Levant.
The Battle of Yarmouk is considered one of the greatest military victories in Islamic history.
what was the significance of the Treaty: The Treaty of Hudaybiyyah was signed in 628 CE between the Muslims of Medina and the Quraysh of Mecca, after a failed attempt by the Muslims to perform Umrah.
While the treaty seemed unfavorable to the Muslims at first, it laid the groundwork for peace and opened the doors for many tribes to accept Islam.
The Treaty of Hudaybiyyah is seen as a strategic victory for the Muslims, as it provided a period of peace that allowed the Muslim community to grow and spread Islam.
what was the Battle of Mu'tah: The Battle of Mu'tah, fought in 629 CE, was the first battle between the Muslims and the Byzantine Empire, near the city of Mu'tah in modern-day Jordan.

The Muslims, led by Zayd ibn Harithah, faced a much larger Byzantine force. Despite the loss of three Muslim commanders, including Zayd, the battle showed the courage and resilience of the Muslim forces.
The Battle of Mu'tah set the stage for further conflicts between the Muslims and the Byzantine Empire and established Khalid ibn al-Walid as a prominent military leader.
who was Khalid ibn al-Walid: Khalid ibn al-Walid, known as the 'Sword of Allah,' was one of the greatest military commanders in Islamic history.
He played a key role in the early Muslim conquests, including the Battle of Yarmouk, the Battle of Mu'tah, and the Battle of Uhud.
Khalid was known for his strategic brilliance, leadership, and undefeated record in battle.
who was Umar ibn al-Khattab: Umar ibn al-Khattab was the second caliph of the Rashidun Caliphate, succeeding Abu Bakr (RA).
He is known for his strong leadership, administrative reforms, and the rapid expansion of the Islamic state into regions such as Persia, Egypt, and Syria.
Umar ibn al-Khattab's rule is often seen as a golden age of the Rashidun Caliphate, marked by justice, fairness, and the spread of Islam.
what is the Battle of Siffin: The Battle of Siffin, fought in 657 CE, was a major conflict between the forces of Ali ibn Abi Talib, the fourth caliph, and Muawiya ibn Abi Sufyan, the governor of Syria.
The battle ended in a stalemate, and the conflict eventually led to the division of the Muslim community, with the emergence of the Sunni and Shia branches of Islam.
The Battle of Siffin is significant for its impact on Islamic political history and the early schism in the Muslim ummah.
what was the significance of the Battle: The Battle of the Camel, fought in 656 CE, was a conflict between the forces of Caliph Ali ibn Abi Talib and those of Aisha, Talha, and Zubair, who sought justice for the killing of Uthman ibn Affan, the third caliph.
Though the battle ended in a decisive victory for Ali, it marked the beginning of internal divisions within the Muslim community.
The Battle of the Camel is significant for its role in the early civil wars of Islam and the disputes over leadership in the caliphate.
what was the Battle of Khyber: The Battle of Khyber, fought in 629 CE, was between the Muslims and the Jewish tribes of Khyber, a stronghold in northern Arabia.
The Muslims, led by Prophet Muhammad (PBUH), were victorious, and the battle resulted in the surrender of the Jewish tribes and the opening of Khyber to Islam.
The victory at Khyber is considered significant because it strengthened the position of the Muslims in the region and led to further conversions to Islam.
what was the significance of the conques: The conquest of Mecca in 630 CE marked the peaceful surrender of the Quraysh to the Muslims and the victory of Islam over the opposition in Mecca.
Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) entered the city with a large army, and he forgave his former enemies, demonstrating mercy and compassion.
The conquest of Mecca is one of the most pivotal events in Islamic history, as it marked the consolidation of Muslim power in Arabia.
who was Ali ibn Abi Talib: Ali ibn Abi Talib was the cousin and son-in-law of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and the fourth caliph of the Rashidun Caliphate.
Ali is known for his courage in battles such as Badr, Uhud, and Khaybar, and his knowledge and wisdom in Islamic jurisprudence.
He is a central figure in both Sunni and Shia Islam, though he is particularly revered by Shia Muslims.
what was the Battle of Badar's impact on: The Battle of Badr was a major victory for the Muslims, despite being outnumbered.
It significantly boosted the morale of the early Muslim community, proving that faith in Allah could lead to victory over the enemies of Islam.
The battle solidified the leadership of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and led to the widespread acceptance of Islam in the Arabian Peninsula.
who were the Ansar: The Ansar were the people of Medina who supported Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and the early Muslim community when they migrated from Mecca to Medina.
The Ansar played a crucial role in the success of the Muslim community during the early years of Islam, offering shelter, protection, and support to the Muhajirun (migrants).
Their support during key battles like Badr and Uhud cemented their position as the helpers of the Prophet.
what is the significance of the Battle o: The Battle of Uhud taught the Muslims important lessons about unity, discipline, and the consequences of disobedience.
Although the Muslims faced defeat, the battle strengthened their resolve and taught them the importance of following the Prophet's instructions.
The battle's significance lies in its role in shaping the character and resilience of the early Muslim community.

what is nust: NUST (National University of Sciences and Technology) is a top-tier Pakistani university known for engineering, computing, and innovation.

pakistan independence day: Pakistan celebrates Independence Day on 14 August 1947.
Independence Day is 14th August, marking the creation of Pakistan in 1947.
when was pakistan founded: The country came into being on 14th August 1947.
founder of pakistan: Quaid-e-Azam Muhammad Ali Jinnah is the founder of Pakistan.
Pakistan's founder is Muhammad Ali Jinnah, known as Quaid-e-Azam.
who is quaid e azam: Quaid-e-Azam Muhammad Ali Jinnah led the Pakistan Movement and became the nation's first Governor-General.
Muhammad Ali Jinnah is revered as the founder and a symbol of integrity and leadership.
who is muhammad ali jinnah: Muhammad Ali Jinnah (Quaid-e-Azam) was the leader of the Pakistan Movement and Pakistan's first Governor-General.
He is remembered for his vision, determination, and statesmanship.
who is allama iqbal: Allama Muhammad Iqbal was a philosopher-poet who inspired the idea of a separate homeland for Muslims of South Asia.
Iqbal is celebrated for his poetry, thought leadership, and influence on the Pakistan Movement.
who is sir syed ahmad khan: Sir Syed Ahmad Khan was an educationist and reformer who founded the Aligarh Movement to promote modern education.
He emphasized scientific learning and social progress in the subcontinent.
who is abdus salam: Dr. Abdus Salam was a Nobel Prize-winning physicist from Pakistan for his contributions to electroweak theory.
He advanced theoretical physics and helped build Pakistan's scientific institutions.
who is m m alam: Air Commodore M. M. Alam was a celebrated fighter pilot known for his exceptional aerial combat achievements.
M. M. Alam is remembered for valor and skill in the 1965 war.
who is rashid minhas: Pilot Officer Rashid Minhas is a Nishan-e-Haider recipient who sacrificed his life to prevent aircraft hijacking.
Rashid Minhas is honored for supreme courage and patriotism.
what is nishan e haider: Nishan-e-Haider is Pakistan's highest military gallantry award for extraordinary bravery.
It is awarded for acts of supreme valor in the face of the enemy.
capital of pakistan: Islamabad is the capital of Pakistan.
national language of pakistan: Urdu is the national language of Pakistan.
largest city of pakistan: Karachi is the largest city of Pakistan.
The biggest city by population is Karachi.
pakistan flag: The flag of Pakistan is green and white with a crescent and star, symbolizing progress and light.
Pakistan's flag: dark green with a white vertical stripe, crescent, and star.
pakistan anthem: Pakistan's national anthem is Qaumi Tarana, written by Hafeez Jalandhari.
The anthem 'Qaumi Tarana' was composed by Ahmad G. Chagla and penned by Hafeez Jalandhari.
pakistan resolution day: Pakistan Day is observed on 23 March, commemorating the Lahore Resolution of 1940.
defence day: Defence Day is observed on 6 September to honor the armed forces' sacrifices.
6th September is Defence Day in Pakistan.
iqbal day: Iqbal Day is observed on 9 November in memory of Allama Iqbal.
9th November is celebrated as Iqbal Day.
quaid day: Quaid Day is observed on 25 December, the birthday of Muhammad Ali Jinnah.
25th December is celebrated as Quaid Day.
kashmir day: Kashmir Day is observed on 5 February to show solidarity with the people of Kashmir.
